Something wrong with my syntax?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286417
>It IS vulnerable to injection if $id comes from the user and isn't escaped

It comes from the user's id number in the database and its stored in cookies.
Do you think users can just alter cookies and fuck shit up?
My website checks for moderator status by checking if your "godmode" variable is 1 or 0. Do you think users could turn themselves into jannies by altering what number they carry in the cookies?
Shit man. Any better way to make a login system that checks if you're a moderator or not?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286490
>Do you think users can just alter cookies and fuck shit up?
Yes of course, it is trivial to do that. Anything you get from the user can be altered.
>website checks for moderator status by checking if your "godmode" variable is 1 or 0
This is fine. If you need to finetune it, you can create a permissions table.
>users could turn themselves into jannies by altering what number they carry in the cookies
Sure, it's as simple as modifying the cookie to something like 399;update+table+users+set+godmode=1+where+id=399 and now he's a janny. This above probably won't work literally, but you get the idea.
Keep in mind he can just as easily append truncate table universities;truncate table uploads; etc. to the malicious input. They can manipulate it to spit out your sensitive user data too.
As a solution, use prepared statements for everything that comes from the user. That way, you send the query command first and then you send data the server plugs into the query. That way, the server automatically makes sure it's escaped properly so it doesn't matter what the user wrote, it will never be executed as SQL commands.
https://www.w3schools.com/php/php_mysql_prepared_statements.asp
The syntax is more verbose, but this is the proper way to do it. There are probably better videos on this on YT.

Injection is a solved problem, so don't fall for this.

On that note, you're not supposed to give out the primary key to users, you should use a session cookie. If you give out the PK, the haxxorz will be able to guess all of them because they are auto incermented, so they will keep trying until they find someone whose password is iloveyou.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286499

My problem with the janny thing is that even though it's pretty safe to check the godmode status when logging in to the admin panel, there still needs to be something carried in cookies. If I first made it so that it only checks your privileges when you log in to the admin panel. It successfully kept outsiders from logging in. But then I realized that if you're logged in to your normal profile as a normal user, you can just go directly to some part of the admin panel such as adminpanel/settings.php. These different php pages no longer check who is accessing them.

I've used real_escape_string instead of prepared statements because the syntax is difficult to understand and 99% of tutorials on the web use these unsafe methods.

threads.com:
I've been trying for 2 days now to get rid of the static from a song that I convert to Unsigned 8-bit for arduino use. It's perfectly fine in Audacity but the second I export it, it adds tons of static. I'd say it's about half as loud as the song so it's basically unavoidable. Even when I bring the 8bit song back in and remove the static, it re-adds it when I export it. I've tried ffmpeg and other encoders and still nothing.

The song I'm using has lots of reverb and as the song fades at the end, the static also goes quieter so I think it's the reverb causing it. Is there any way around this without removing the reverb? It's a music box style song

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286372
>static from a song that I convert to Unsigned 8-bit
That's because of dithering.
https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dither

There should be a way to disable it in any of the software you tried.
If not, you could use the wave module in Python's standard library.
That would allow you to truncate the samples to 8 bits, without dithering.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286379
I've disabled dithering both in audacity and ffmpeg and still get the same static. I can try uploading a comparison or example if it'd help?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: still would

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286380
Just did some testing on my own, and I got some noise with dithering disabled.
I believe the noise is caused by quantization error.
There's a small square wave that comes from samples getting rounded up or down.

It's not a lot, though, and it doesn't sound like static.
Maybe your playback software/hardware is adding the noise when converting from 8bits per sample.
Like adding noise to an image to combat banding.

Well, a workaround for you might be to use a chiptune of the song instead.
Something like that:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RAoKPxazEGE
The sound is much less likely to be affected by quantization.
It'd be fitting, too, for an electronic music box.

threads.com: can you convert an mkv file with subtitles to avi while retaining those subtitles? what's the best software to do this?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: Try vidcoder

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286108
mkv is a container. If you have "soft subs", they're in this container and can be extracted via software like mkvtoolnix. You can then manipulate them and serve them by the avi's side. Most players will pick them up automatically if they have the same name as the video file.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286108
like >>1286120 says mkvtoolnix to extract the embedded subtitle stream if it is soft subbed ie you can turn subs on and off. avi format was not intended or designed to contain a substream, just audio and video streams that are now days antiquated. Some people have extended avi format to contain things it was never intended to contain but this is non standard and may not work on most users' systems.

if the movie is hard subbed just convert container to an avi using ffmpeg or avidemux.

If the mkv is softsubbed you can reencode with avidemux with sub options set to hardcode subs

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
So, I’m wanting to access my garage door through my phone for fun and I’m going to do it with a raspberry pi and a relay I have laying around.

The actual garage door motor has some “special” features that make it difficult to operate with the stuff I have currently. My solution is to use a garage door remote, solder wires to the button contacts and then run that to the relay.

My concern is that my relay is a 5v relay, but the garage remote takes a 3v coin battery. Obviously I want to remove the battery and power it with my relay, but I’m not sure if the power coming from the relay will damage the remote.

Sorry if this is a dumb question, I’m a software developer by trade but I don’t really know anything about electrical stuff and I’m trying to learn. Any insight is appreciated.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286276
>Obviously I want to remove the battery and power it with my relay
No you don't, that defeats the purpose of a relay. If you're not going to have electrical isolation, you don't need a relay and can just connect the pin directly or through a transistor, or whatever it was you're using to drive the relay (hopefully you're not connecting it to the pin directly, that will blow the pin).

Anyways, Pi has a +3.3V pin that will probably be fine.
https://www.circuits.dk/everything-about-raspberry-gpio/
If it was me, I'd work out if the button pulled up or down, then connect a GPIO directly to whatever the button connects to and drive it instead of the button. Pi is 3.3V logic, so it will probably be fine, particularly if it's pulling down, as asking the Pi to sink 2.8ish Volts will be no problem for it. If it's pulling up, and you really cared, you could add a voltage divider.

But you're probably best using a prefabricated relay module, and a prefabricated 5V->3V voltage regulator and a prefabricated USB socket. Don't connect the pi directly to anything, use the relay as an electrically-isolated switch.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286304
Ah, I see what you’re saying.

The plan I had was that I would go from the Pi to the relay and then from the relay to the garage remote and I just wasn’t sure if the 5v from the relay would damage the 3v garage remote.

This is probably impossible to tell with just words, but my assumption was that the button on the garage remote just worked to complete the circuit causing the door to open. So if I removed the battery from the remote and soldered a wire to connect the contacts from either side of the button on the remote then the power from the relay would power the completed circuit causing the door to open. I touched a copper wire to either side of the connections on remote and it opened the garage door, so that’s where the assumption came from.

I think what you said about powering whatever the button came to would be much smarter, but I literally just started looking into all of this yesterday and I think I might have too little knowledge at the moment to attempt something like that

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286320
>if I removed the battery from the remote and soldered a wire to connect the contacts from either side of the button on the remote then the power from the relay would power the completed circuit causing the door to open.
Relays don't provide power, a "5V relay" means one that will switch when you supply 5V over its coil.
The point of relays is to electrically isolate the circuit connected to the switch from the one connected to the coil. There's no connection between the two sides of the relay.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286105

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286118
Maybe, but I didn't see many that matched

>>1286122
It does have the rolling part but no tongue

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286139
slide buckle, then

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286105
Friction buckle. There are at least three designs called that.

The one used on backpack shoulder straps and things like that that you don't want to frequently adjust.

The one you've got used on belts where the fixed end of the belt is is attached to the central sliding bar.

Another is sometimes called a roller friction buckle. The fixed end of the belt is attached to the end of a rectangular shaped tube or three sided channel. The tube has a slanted channel that holds a rough edged bar. When the free end pulls backwards through this tube it drags the bar and because of the slant the bar squashed the belt so it can't slide. pic related

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
I have a table with some data, let's say

+---+------+
| id | text |
+---+------+
| 1 + a +
+---+------+
| 2 + b +
+---+------+

and a list (separated by commas), let's say:

(1,2,3,5)

What could I do If I want to know the numbers of the list which are not included in the ids from the table.

In this case it would be the 3 and 5.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
If you're using the Python MySQL connector, you could iterate through the list and search for each id in the database, then return a list of the values with no match. In Python, it would look like this:
#Import connector, initialize connection and cursor
list = [1, 2, 3, 5]
returnlist = []
for x in list:
cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM TABLE WHERE id=" + str(x)) #Replace TABLE with table name
if (not cursor.fetchone()):
returnlist.append(x)
print(returnlist)
Something like that should do the trick.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286110
That's kind of odd, querying a database for what's not in it. Regardless, a totally SQL approach would be to create a temporary table with the range of IDs in it, select id FROM temp where temp.id not in table. Not got a database in front of me so you'll have to figure out the syntax yourself.

>>1286290
Using Python, retrieve all the ids from the DB into a set and take the difference with set(range(1,6)).

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com: I was imaging my C drive onto a partition of my D drive and it formated the whole thing. I stopped it at 1% of the imaging process. Is there a way I can recover my old D drive. It had a lot of data(4 TB), is recovering that possible ? What are some good data recovery software, are they any clear best?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286204
That's why you back your shit up.
Two is one and one is none.

If the drive was formatted with GPT, there's a backup table at the end of the drive that you could restore.
Here's a guy who was in the same situation as yours:
https://superuser.com/questions/1508109/gpt-table-recovery

Since the drive is more than 2TB, it's unlikely that it was formatted with MBR instead.
If it somehow was, then you'll have to use some partition recovery software.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286204
You should be able to recover a lot of data but recovering all data is not likely because that overwritten 1% is extremely unlikely to recoverable short of advanced forensic recovery tools and hardware. Due to the way windows stores files, lots of fragmentation and files scattered all over the disk, it is possible that the 1% of completely overwritten disk doesn't just affect 1% of the content, it could and probably will affect many files that each have a tiny portion of their content in that 1% region. Even one block missing from a file can corrupt the file to uselessness

If restoring the partition info like >>1286226 says doesn't work to make the drive readable under Windows, I'm going to say use Linux as I like the tools better. If Linux doesn't restore the partition so you can mount and read it under Windows you will want a >= 4TB disk to recover files onto.

If you have a spare HDD or SSD, doesn't have to be large, 20 GB would probably work well, install Linux to that, or run it off a thumbdrive. The HDD or SSD will be faster than thumbdrive.

Depending on the Linux distro and the route you take, you may need to manually install a few extra tools like gparted (to work with partitions), protorec (recovers files not just photos), ntfs-3g (to be able to read from ntfs disks), testdisk (recover partitions). Look those up. I'd recommend something like Ubuntu or Mint as they're pretty user friendly for someone new to Linux and they are well supported

A 4 TB drive might take a while to process especially if the file structure is lost. Probably worth it to recover personal photos and docs, but if it's games and movies, might be more trouble than it's worth.

And again, like you've been told, backup your data.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286087
Formulae start with =

Most formulae support ranges. If your data are in a column the range would look like A1:A10, in a row B2:K2, if multiple rows and columns C3:F6

If you copy a formulae with a cell reference, when you paste it the cell reference will changer
for example, you copy =count(A1) and you paste it one column to the right it will become =count(B1). To stop the reference change put a $ in front of the thing. $A1 will keep the A constant, A$1 will keep the one constant, $A$1 will keep both constant

if you want to count non empty cells use count
=count(A2:B6)

if you want to count things that match a condition use count if
=countif(A2:B6, "pattern")
or if the pattern is the value in a cell
=countif(A2:B6, D7)

You can make as many new columns as you want.

One thing thing that might help is if
=if(cell="value", true, false)
for example putting this in cells in column B will fill the cells with 1 if the cell in column A has the value Y, but 0 for anything else including empty
=if(A1 = "Y", 1, 0)

AND might help, you can put AND inside IF and COUNTIF
=IF(AND(A1 = 10, B1 >= 3), true, false)

if you want averages and standard deviations then look up the function names and they will look like
=functionname(range)

You can compare times, add times, subtract times etc if you select the cells that contain times and make sure thwy are formatted as time. Cells start off as General. The option is found on the home tab of the ribbon.

part1 might use a new column with
=if(and(E1="Y", F1 < 21),1,0)
then you can SUM the new column to find how many rows are true at the same time

There are better ways to do this with COUNTIF and nested IF and nested AND and NOT but it would help for you to know how to use formulae first or you'll get confused and I'm not going to do any more of your homework for you. Part of the reason school gives you homework is to get you to learn your own stuff and reinforce your understanding.

reencode it once to 144 pixels then reencode it again but enlarge it to 1080, or for less processing power needed and smaller file size reencode just once to 144 with its display size to 1080. Either way unless you do a straight pixel resize when enlarging it will be obvious that the file has been resized.

protip: 1080 / 144 = 7.5 is not an integer therefore you can't do straight pixel resize because the 8th pixel will be an average of 7th and 9th.

good luck finding widths and heights of smaller and larger resolutions that are integer valued ratios of each other at aspect ratio you want

another protip: Don't talk about 144p quality. 144 is a resolution not a quality. Video files have storage resolutions, display resolutions which can be different to storage as the stored pixels can be stretched or compressed which is why I said you can reencode it just once to 144 storage height with 1080 display height which will stretch pixels when displayed, and quality settings within which are independent of resolution. 720p with high crf can look better 1080p with low crf if people want to encode like that.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286013
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1unkluyh2Ks
>Pixels
Smallest unit of an image, basically a square of color. When you zoom in on an image in MS Paint, you end up seeing squares. Those are the pixels.
>Resolution
How many pixels you got in an image.
>Height/Width
Since pixels are square, computers like 2D arrays (tables) and cinema film is rectangular, displaying digital images as rectangles has become the standard. Rectangles can be expressed by their height and width. If those are expressed by pixel count, multiplying them gives you the image's resolution. If by length units, it gives you the dimensions of the printed image.
>[Physical] Size
Digital images can be displayed on screens and printed on paper. There is a measure of pixel density named "pixels per inch" (PPI) which is fairly self-explanatory. If you keep your PPI constant and increase your resolution, the physical size of the image grows (you have more of an image). If you keep your resolution constant and increase the PPI, the physical size shrinks (the image becomes denser). If you keep your resolution constant and increase the physical size, the PPI drops and your printed image looks more pixelated (like zooming in in Paint and seeing large pixels).
When doing digital art, physical size matters not. You usually grab a default PPI value like 72 and the program does the conversion on its own. If you're working with prints, then it's important to know the required PPI so you can have the correct resolution for a given size of print.

threads.com: What internet speed do I need to have to get an average ping that is below 15ms from a server that is located 1000km away? I need to get a new internet package as my current internet is not fast enough and I need to get an idea of how strong my internet has to be.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286016
Speed and latency are two different things, your ping to a given server won't be any lower with 500Mbps than it will with 50Mbps because the server is the same physical distance away.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286016
Internet speed does not affect ping

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1286059
>>1286029
Uplink speed does not affect ping, provided you don't saturate it and make it start queueing, but more expensive plans and more expensive ISPs will take more expensive more direct routes, and get their packets forwarded at a higher priority.

So there's not a linear correlation*, but there is a correlation.

* beyond the simple "one 1500 byte packet takes (1500*1000)/your-line-speed milliseconds to send down the final mile", which isn't that relevant anymore with modern packages: old 8MB DSL though has 1MB upload, which means while packets take 1.5ms to download, they take 12ms to upload. So you're probably going to want a technology with at least 8Mbps upload, if a round-trip time of 15ms is your goal.

If you are offered a work machine, absolutely take it. Use it do do all your work on it, and nothing else. Use your private devices for everything else, but do not connect via work's internet. Use mobile data if you must.
